description: Aromas of tomato sauce and fresh green herbs set up true-to-Carmenère flavors of salty, herbal plum and berry. On the finish, typical varietal flavors of olive, herbs and spice are saucy.
title: Tres Palacios 2013 Family Vintage Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: This has a dense bouquet, with aromas of beet, clove, mint, tomato and berry fruit. The mouthfeel is rich and saturated, with a rawness that didn't exist in prior years. Flavors of mixed herb, earth and savory berry end with a long finish.
title: Concha y Toro 2009 Terrunyo Entre Cordilleras Peumo Vineyard Carmenère (Peumo)

description: Rustic, as Carmenère should be, this single-valley offering is a good drink-with-barbecue bet. Bark, dark berries and chocolatey aromas show on the nose; earth and black fruit dominate the full, low-acid palate. Woodsy, briary notes and ample spice give oomph to the juicy berry finish.
title: Morandé 2001 Terrarum Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: This smells forced and grapy, with murky undertones. Flabby on the palate, this organic red tastes nutty and earthy. An aftertaste of mulch and peanut is off base and highly questionable.
title: Teillery 2014 Organic Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Piercing woody aromas create a fiery nose of spicy red-fruit scents. Narrow, gritty and scratchy in feel, this tastes of red-berry fruits, vanilla and buttery oak. The finish hints at buttered movie popcorn.
title: In Situ 2013 Reserva Estate Bottled Carmenère (Aconcagua Valley)

description: Herbal aromas of tomato leaf and bell pepper are typical of Carmenère. This feels clipped and choppy, while flavors of herbal plum and berry turn in the direction of bell pepper prior to a raw, scratchy finish.
title: Tres Palacios 2013 Reserve Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Spicy, herbal and toasty on the nose, but the palate fails to meet the promise of the aromas. It's acidic and sharp at its center, with grabby tannins along with regular plum and boysenberry flavors. A big-bodied red with rough tannins and outsized acidity.
title: San Pedro 2007 Castillo de Molina Reserva Carmenère (Maule Valley)

description: Along with the Carmenère from Reininger, this stylish example belongs in the cellar of anyone with a hunger for this unusual variety. The green olive/herbal nature of the grape is carefully managed, and provides a nuance rather than a dominant flavor. At the core is tart red berry fruit and a wash of dark chocolate.
title: Nodland 2009 Avant Garde Carmenère (Walla Walla Valley (WA))

description: Spicy, tarry, gritty aromas of asphalt and olive drive the bouquet. This feels ripe and full bodied, with stewed plum, herb and cardamom flavors. Toast, dark-berry flavors and mint are the key notes to the finish.
title: San Pedro 2011 1865 Single Vineyard Carmenère (Maule Valley)

description: Herb, spice, wild berry and wood aromas set up a round palate that's bigger than medium but not huge in size. Definitive Carmenère flavors of herbs, wild berry and spiced plum finish with moderate bitterness and tannic support.
title: Casa Silva 2012 Los Lingues Vineyard Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Savory, spicy aromas of saucy fruit, fennel and sausage are gamy, herbal and interesting. This is plush and big on the palate, with weight and depth. Flavors of spiced plum and berry are ripe given that 2011 was a cool year for warm-weather varieties like this.
title: Viña Tarapacá 2011 Gran Reserva Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Herbal aromas of green tobacco, black fruits and coffee grounds require some understanding of Carmenère to fully appreciate. A chunky, saturated palate is thick but balanced by tartaric acidity. Herbal, minty blackberry flavors are woody and show a hint of graphite, while coffee, carob and burnt toast flavors blend with green notes on the finish. Drink through 2020.
title: San Pedro 2015 1865 Single Vineyard Carmenère (Maule Valley)

description: Good body and a fair amount of richness here. The nose is on the heavier, rubbery side, and it dulls down rather than expands. On the palate, Huique is warm, sweet, figgy and a little syrupy, with soft fruit and a touch of bitterness on the finish.
title: El Huique 2007 Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Hard, spicy and rubbery on the nose, with ripe, semi-baked flavors of rubber, black fruit and hardy oak. There's a ton of wood spice and clove as it opens, and nothing is finessed. Dark and chocolaty on the finish, with even more oak.
title: Veranda 2007 Oda Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Roasted, floral, candied aromas precede a zesty, medium-weight palate of red plum, cherry and herbal flavors. The palate is juicy and acidic, with racy red fruit and scour and scrape to the finish. Straightforward Carmenère without much softness or richness.
title: Echeverria 2007 Reserva Carmenère (Central Valley)

description: Tea, spice and modest berry aromas make for a reticent nose. This feels jammy and spongey, while medicinal, herbal berry and oak flavors veer towards minty green and resin on the finish.
title: Casas del Toqui 2013 Terroir Selection Gran Reserva Carmenère (Peumo)

description: Herbal, wiry red-fruit aromas kick this off, followed by a spunky, jumpy palate. Flavors of plum, raspberry and tomato are saucy and herbal, while the finish is good, with modest acidity keeping the wine stable and balanced.
title: La Playa 2012 Block Selection Reserve Block N.13 Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Old-style Carmenère with green bean, mocha and muddy berry aromas. Tight and more acidic than expected, with generic red berry, chocolate and mocha flavors along with a palpable wave of green. Finishes quick and crisp.
title: San Elias 2010 Carmenère (Central Valley)

description: Rooty, minty aromas of blackberry and boysenberry are heavy on the nose. This feels blocky and full-bodied, with loamy, jammy black-fruit flavors that show a typical varietal greeness. A finish with herbal, tomatoey flavors includes a dusting of chocolate.
title: Odfjell 2013 Armador Carmenère (Central Valley)

description: Classic Carmenère aromas of oregano, basil and tomato vie with ripe plum and spice to create an herbal-leaning but honest bouquet. Feels good, with balance and lift to flavors of berry, olive, tobacco and herbs. Mild and short on the finish, but nice for $10.
title: oops 2010 Carmenère (Central Valley)

description: Leathery, herbal aromas of black fruits, horsehide and murky earth lead to a medium-bodied palate with wiry acidity. Saucy, herbal tomato and plum flavors are typical of the variety, while the finish maintains the wine's true-to-form flavors.
title: Viña Tarapacá 2014 Gran Reserva Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Stalky, herbal aromas of leather, olive, asphalt and berry fruits come in front of a clampy but fresh palate with hard tannins. Briny, herbal black-plum flavors fit the common profile for Carmenère, while this is slightly astringent on the finish.
title: Apaltagua 2014 Reserva Carmenère (Apalta)

description: Leafy aromas of field brush accent cassis, plum and oak-based clove scents. This feels obtuse and on the heavy side. Generic black-fruit flavors include a hint of raisin, while this Carmenère also tastes spicy and peppery. Baked berry flavors lead a chunky finish.
title: Ventisquero 2014 Reserva Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Stocky yet comported up front, this dark-colored Carmenère pumps out blackberry aromas along with notes of dried herbs and desert brush. A full but balanced palate deals toasty, blackened plum and spice flavors in front of a finish with ample oak and baking-spice notes.
title: Undurraga 2014 Sibaris Gran Reserva Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Aromas of cola, blackberry, cherry and mild herbs are cool and collected. Feels good, chunky and round, with plum, raspberry and more than enough herbal essence in the backdrop. Finishes herbal, spicy and peppery, which is textbook for this variety.
title: Anakena 2010 Single Vineyard Plot: Malva Carmenère (Peumo)

description: Dense and a bit green on the nose, with oak-based aromas of coffee to go with graphite and blackberry. Feels thick, creamy and resiny, with oak-led flavors of coconut, chocolate, vanilla and herbs along with black fruit. Finishes minty, with tobacco notes and heat.
title: Casas del Bosque 2010 Reserva Carmenère (Rapel Valley)

description: Raspberry, tomato leaf and a spot of rhubarb give the nose a crisp outlook. The palate is zesty and linear, with herbal strawberry and raspberry flavors kissed by oak-based mocha. Creamy on the finish, with spice more than residual fruit. A nice ride, and solid for Carmenère. Imported by Republic National Distributors.
title: Portal Del Alto 2005 Gran Reserva Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Straightforward plum and currant aromas are lightly spiced. This is medium in body, with herbal and slightly bitter plum flavors that finish medicinal.
title: François Lurton 2013 Hacienda Araucano Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: At first take, the aromas are of barbecued meats, beets and earth; later some lemony oak emerges. The fruit here is nice: It's a clean mix of cassis and cherry, with toasty oak-based undercurrents. Very solid and sturdy, and a bit charred at the edges. Try it for a positive look into modern Carmenère.
title: Casa Silva 2001 Reserve - Est Bottled Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Hard, rubbery blackberry and black-currant flavors are herbal but settle with airing. This feels round, fresh and fair. Flavors of spiced plum, blackberry, carob and generic spices finish dark and foresty, with good overall balance.
title: Undurraga 2013 Gran Reserva Sibaris Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Plum and cherry aromas are generic in nature. This feels jammy and candied, while heavy berry fruit and oak flavors combine to keep things basic and muddled.
title: Viña Bisquertt 2012 La Joya Gran Reserva Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Raw, leafy aromas announce a hard, astringent wine with green, herbal flavors of juniper and raspberry. A rubbery finish confirms that this is base level and acceptable in the scheme of things.
title: Cremaschi Furlotti 2011 Single Vineyard Carmenère (Loncomilla Valley)

description: Murky, earthy aromas mark the nose—a blend of tomato, herb and meat notes. It feels good, with herbal-berry flavors and grapy thickness. It finishes with a flash of acidity, a note of coconutty oak and a final herbal blast.
title: Calina 2010 Carmenère (Central Valley)

description: Standard berry, plum and herb aromas set up a gummy-feeling palate, with a berry flavor and a hint of fine herbs. It shows texture and a black olive flavor on the finish.
title: Santa Ema 2010 Selected Terroir Carmenère (Cachapoal Valley)

description: A toasty but green-smelling bouquet mixes scents of grass with charred oak and berry fruits. A creamy, lactic palate deals flavors of green herbs, mint and milk chocolate, all of which carry over to a minty finish.
title: Valle Hermoso 2015 Elegido Gran Reserva Carmenère (Colchagua Costa)

description: This is one aggressive varietal wine. The nose is packed with sweaty leather and olive notes, while the palate is rough and tart at the edges. There are notes of cola and burnt coffee on the finish, but by then you may just grow tired of wrestling with it.
title: TerraNoble 2005 Reserva Carmenère (Maule Valley)

description: Rough, green and olive-dominated on the nose. The palate is plump to the point of being weighty, while the flavors are briary and run heavy with olive, green tobacco and green bean. Mild on the finish, with another wave of green olive.
title: Morandé 2009 Reserva Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Hits heavy with the olive and burnt rubber aromas, then turns ultrazesty and citric in the mouth. Tastes tangy and herbal, with tomato and sour plum flavors. A raw, tart wine.
title: Root:1 2009 Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: A bright magenta color and aromas of blueberry juice and wet dog suggest a basic wine that's all about fruit and not much about style or complexity. The palate is lively and juicy, the flavors are vivacious but immature, and the finish falls off fast.
title: Sombras del Sol 2011 Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Rooty licorice, leather and olive aromas are solid, with pleasing berry scents. This feels plump, with a touch of tartaric acid popping up. Peppery plum and olive flavors are textbook for the variety, while the finish is forward and robust.
title: Undurraga 2013 Sibaris Reserva Especial Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Grown primarily in Chile these days, Carmenère can be akin to Merlot, though this version has the herbal qualities of a Cab Franc and is otherwise quite oaky.
title: Yorkville Cellars 2009 Rennie Vineyard Carmenère (Yorkville Highlands)

description: Phinny Hill is in the Horse Heaven Hills AVA of Washington, a prestigious location near Champoux and other high end growers. This Carmenère has 5% Syrah added, but the varietal character dominates, with strong green leaf and herb flavors. The tannins are woody and the fruit fragrant with blackberry and cassis. Good varietal expression is the hallmark of this wine.
title: Nuthatch Cellars 2008 Phinny Hill Vineyard Carmenère (Columbia Valley (WA))

description: This is a yes/no sort of grape, as far as individual preferences go. If you are a yes, this is a good one. It captures and contains the varietal streak of herb and stem, with ample tart berry fruit to balance.
title: Season 2014 Limited Edition Series Carmenère (Southern Oregon)

description: Black cherry, blackberry, olive and gritty oak aromas feed into a scratchy palate with forceful acidity. Oaky, blackened flavors of medicinal berry fruits finish with notes of mint and carob. Overall, this is solid but typically herbal and saucy.
title: Concha y Toro 2013 Casillero del Diablo Reserva Carmenère (Central Valley)

description: In this racy, full-bodied wine, olive, spice, chocolate and berry aromas come in front of a flush but acidic palate with a tartaric influence. Herbal red-berry and olive flavors finish long and lasting, with a tomato note.
title: Undurraga 2010 Founder's Collection Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Lavender, thyme, rosemary and other green herb notes dot the nose, which leads to a solid, cushioned palate with sweet berry, leaf, spice and carob flavors. Finishes sweet, with melted chocolate and heft. Just short of excellent but still the best Carmenère yet from François Lurton's Colchagua property.
title: François Lurton 2007 Hacienda Araucano Alka Carmenère (Lolol Valley)

description: Coffee, mint and earthy blackberry aromas open this rich, ripe—almost unctuous—Carmenère. Spiced berry and lightly herbal black plum flavors finish full and balanced, while ending flavors of dark-roast coffee, chocolate and herbs are just right.
title: Arboleda 2012 Carmenère (Aconcagua Valley)

description: Aromas are drawn and mildly green in nature. In the mouth, this is soft and stewy, with as much green herb and mint as berry fruit and richness. On the finish, this feels syrupy but tastes a bit like salad, with candied sweetness thrown in.
title: Ventisquero 2010 Grey [Glacier] Single Block Trinidad Vineyard Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Dusty blackberry and dark plum aromas come with spice, particulary pepper. Feels crisp, juicy and tight on the palate, with plum, cherry, red licorice candy and peppery flavors. Dry on the finish, and only slightly herbal overall.
title: Emiliana 2010 Natura Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Staunch but murky aromas of coffee grounds, leafy berry, olive and lemon peel announce a tight raw palate. Flavors of olive, plum skins and herbs finish with a reprise of spent coffee along with scratchy tannins.
title: Viña el Aromo 2011 Private Reserve Carmenère (Maule Valley)

description: The aromas of black fruit, black olive and herb are solid. Racy and tangy due to pushy acidity, this has berry, herb and vanilla flavors. Fresh in feel but basic in flavor.
title: Botalcura 2009 La Porfia Gran Reserva Carmenère (Maule Valley)

description: Rubbery, herbal aromas of stalky black fruits are typical of the variety but also gritty and horsey smelling. This has a snappy, grating mouthfeel and flavors of herbal blackberry and plum along with an acid-driven palate. Licorice, oak and vanilla flavors are present on the finish.
designation: Reserva Espiritu de Los Andes Estate Bottled
title: Santa Alicia 2014 Reserva Espiritu de Los Andes Estate Bottled Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Aromas of green bean, shoe polish, carob and blackberry are heavy and oaky. A creamy weight dominates the palate, which also shows an unbalanced streak of tartaric acid. Herbal blackberry, plum and licorice flavors finish minty, with a resinous oak feel.
title: Santa Luz 2014 Reserva Encinos Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Oaky aromas of sawdust vie with herbal, leafy notes on the nose of this Carmenère. Roasted black-plum flavors finish with grabby, rubbery tannins.
title: Santa Alicia 2013 Gran Reserva de Los Andes Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Gritty, charred, spicy aromas muscle out black-fruit notes on a peppery bouquet. This feels acidic, while flavors of berry fruits come with oaky notes of carob and mint. A chunky, resiny finish closes this out.
title: Viña Maipo 2013 Vitral Reserva Carmenère (Chile)

description: This absurdly priced Carmenère is always one of Chile's best, and this vintage is just fine, with cherry, cassis, graphite, herb and eucalyptus-like green aromas. The palate is chunky and round in feel, with solid acidity and plump, herbal flavors of berry fruits, olive and spice. But what justifies a $235 price tag? You can be the judge.
title: Errazuriz 2010 Kai Carmenère (Aconcagua Valley)

description: This medium-bodied Carmenère offers blackberry, oak and white-pepper flavors and herb, wood and blueberry aromas. Good for a group; will appeal to a wide audience.
title: Portal Del Alto 2000 Gran Reserva Carmenère (Maule Valley)

description: Compact and dark in style, with notes of shoe polish, coconut, rubber, violet and blackberry. It feels tannic and mildly abrasive, with blackened, ripe flavors of dark berry fruits backed by a peppery, spice-dominant finish. This blend of Carmenère, Syrah and Cabernet is oaky and big overall.
title: Koyle 2009 Royale Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Plum, berry, licorice and balsamic aromas are earthy and classy. This feels chunky and heavy but not ponderous. Flavors of prune, rooty spices, mint and chocolate finish with mocha and fig notes. Enjoy this ripe, full-bodied wine anytime through 2017.
title: San Pedro 2010 Tierras Moradas Carmenère (Maule Valley)

description: Tomato leaf, red bell pepper and dry spice aromas overrun the fruit, and in the mouth it's rather tart and acidic for the grape type. Flavors of cherry tomato, red plum and green herbs are good but sharp, while the finish features oak in the form of vanilla. More fresh and tart than most Carmenères.
title: Botalcura 2007 La Porfia Grand Reserve Carmenère (Curicó Valley)

description: Earthy and damp smelling, with chunky black cherry and olive aromas. The palate has a slightly choppy feel and then spicy, sweet flavors of herbs and blackberry. Finishes a little burnt and bitter, but overall there's enough sweetness and ripeness to offset any herbal qualities.
title: Miguel Torres 2009 Santa Digna Reserve Carmenère (Central Valley)

description: One of the best value-priced, big and rich wines you're likely to find. The nose impresses with potent blackberry, cedar and marzipan aromas, and the palate bridges the gap between power and elegance. Tastes great, with herbal black cherry and cola leading the way. Very ripe but really well made.
title: Lapostolle 2008 Casa Carmenère (Rapel Valley)

description: Herbal and leathery smelling, with a grassy quality to the bouquet. Feels choppy and tannic, with jumbled, stewy flavors that turn more herbal and hot on the finish. Entirely underwhelming.
title: Anakena 2009 Single Vineyard Carmenère (Peumo)

description: Green, herbal aromas are varietally common and share bouquet space with plum and berry notes. Plump and chunky in feel, this tastes of oregano, rosemary, olive and wood resin along with plum and berry. An oaky, lactic finish is herbal, true to Carmenère and ultimately a bit green.
title: Vistamar 2013 Reserva Sepia Carmenère (Cachapoal Valley)

description: Berry aromas are followed by a round, wholesomeness that can't be criticized. The palate is unlike many a Carmenère because it eschews the herbal, green element that's inherent to the grape, and instead offers plum, blackberry and all the richness one can conjure. A round, finish of light oak and vanilla seals it all in fine fashion. Surely the most jammy, expressive and pure Carmenère that Chile has to offer.
title: Concha y Toro 2000 Terrunyo Carmenère (Peumo)

description: Tarry, black-fruit aromas show a touch of oaky vanilla. This has a medium-bodied palate feel along with stalky, slightly horsey flavors of berry fruits and plum. A loamy finish sets out strong and settles on mild earthiness.
title: La Playa 2013 Block Selection Tinga Reserve Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Cool aromas of cola and dark fruits come with bold spice accents. Ripe and creamy in feel, with wild berry and peppery flavors, this Carmenère from a cool vintage is on the money as it finishes with a strong oak base and related spice notes.
title: Caliterra 2013 Tributo Single Vineyard Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Peppery berry aromas show a balsamic nature. This feels fully oaked and resiny, while bold, fruity flavors of ripe black grapes, plum and peppercorn finish with a wave of heavy oak and mint.
title: Arboleda 2013 Carmenère (Aconcagua Valley)

description: Spicy, earthy aromas are warm and fairly deep, while a snappy, acidic palate of berry fruit supported buy buttery oak does the trick. The finish is substantive and only mildly tannic, while the overall personality is fresh and clean.
title: Santa Alicia 2001 Estate Bottled Reserve Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Herbal blackberry aromas include gritty notes of road tar and eucalyptus that are derivative of the Petit Verdot and Cab Franc that have been mixed into this Carmenère. Sandpaper tannins create a dry scratchy mouthfeel, while peppery, spicy, blackened berry flavors finish with massive tannins. Drink this bullish bomber through 2023.
title: Estampa 2014 Gold Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Supple and bursting with ripe purple fruits, this is a real success. The grape's stemmy and green character is held in restraint, and the purple plummy fruit flavors come through in a sweet core, surrounded with flavors of espresso, dark chocolate and stem. Well balanced and firm, this is a wine to enjoy now through 2022.
title: Plaisance Ranch 2014 Carmenère (Applegate Valley)

description: Spice and herbal berry aromas are true to the variety. Hard acidity creates roughness and scratch on the palate, while chocolaty, spiced plum flavors finish fiery at first then with herbal red-fruit flavors as it fades.
title: Alta Delta 2011 Carmenère (Curicó Valley)

description: Blueberry aromas come with an exotic note of cardamom. In the mouth, it feels flat, with rubbery tannins. Flavors of herbal berry and tomato leaf are briny and have a plastic-like taste, while herbal notes of oregano and tomato dominate the finish.
title: Anakena 2011 Tama Vineyard Selection Carmenère (Cachapoal Valley)

description: Jumpy and aggressive on the nose, with a mix of charred, burnt, meaty aromas and saline, this struggles to register. A grabby, sticky, roasted palate tastes burnt and herbal, while the finish is charred and chocolaty.
title: Von Siebenthal 2010 Gran Reserva Single Vineyard Carmenère (Aconcagua Valley)

description: Raspberry and plum aromas carry hints of lemon and flower. It tastes solid, with flavors of herb, meaty berry, plum and lemony oak. There's a spiciness, with spiky acidity on the finish that feels forced.
title: Oveja Negra 2010 Single Vineyard Carmenère (Maule Valley)

description: Rubbery, herbaceous aromas of iodine, grass and black olive are challenging to say the least. This is high in tartaric acid, with saucy, herbal berry flavors that finish with residual olive notes.
title: Ventisquero 2013 Reserva Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: A dark berry aroma comes with a distinct whiff of green. On the palate, the wine feels crisp and clampy, while the flavors of spicy, herbal plum and berry teeter on the edge of being green. It tastes briary and like tomato sauce on the finish.
title: Echeverria 2010 Limited Edition Carmenère (Curicó Valley)

description: Intense and compact on the nose, this has cola, mint, cassis and blackberry aromas that are tightly knit. The palate is narrow and intense, with lightly herbal, reedy flavors of saucy, savory berry and herb. This is a leading Carmenère, but it's not as flavorful and substantive as prior years.
title: Concha y Toro 2009 Carmín de Peumo Carmenère (Cachapoal Valley)

description: Familiar aromas of herbs and olive make up the nose along with berry scents and hints of tree bark and mocha. A choppy palate is shrill with tartaric acidity. Spicy berry and plum flavors turn lean on a scrubbing finish.
title: Criterion 2013 Reserva Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Aromas of animal hide, rubber and herbal berry fruits are not lovable. This has a heavy scratchy mouthfeel and lightly green flavors of berry fruits mixed with unabsorbed oak. This tastes toasty and blackened on an abrasive finish.
title: Santa Rita 2015 Reserva Carmenère (Rapel Valley)

description: Not overtly green smelling, but thisdeals herbal aromas of olive and eucalyptus. Lean and scratchy on the palate, with citrusy, reticent flavors of light red fruits and leaves. There's not much to the finish.
title: Chilcas 2010 Reserva Carmenère (Maule Valley)

description: The punchy nose brings spice notes that are sharp on the inhale. This is tight on the palate, with tartaric acid rising up through a medium-weight body. Black plum, cherry, oak and spice flavors finish dry but hollow.
title: Primus 2013 Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)

description: Asphalt, animal hide, olive and herbal berry aromas spell out Carmenère. This is fresh and medium in body, with oaky, herbal plum and raspberry flavors that taste a bit burnt and crusty. Mint and herbal flavors carry the finish on this respectable value offering.
title: Anakena 2013 Enco Reserve Carmenère (Cachapoal Valley)

description: Cranberry and raspberry comprise the red-fruit nose, and next is the aroma of horse hide and a heavy dose of oak. The fruity palate is all about plum and cassis, and on the finish everything is in place and the texture is firm.
title: Carmen 2001 Carmenère (Rapel Valley)

description: There's brightness here, though the wine's flavors are a little strange. The nose is a mix of wet soil, caramel and clarified butter; the palate offers the same wet-soil flavor, plus plum and wood. Not nuanced; closes with herb and metal.
title: Agustinos 2000 Reserve Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Plum, raspberry, dried herb and light spice aromas lead to a choppy but solid palate. Oaky flavors of toast and coffee sit atop blackberry fruit, while this finishes with richness and dominating barrel-driven flavors of spice and toast.
title: Valle Secreto 2013 First Edition Carmenère (Cachapoal Valley)

description: Saucy, herbal aromas of tarry berry, olive, carob and mint set up a crisp palate that's lean in composition. Generic plum and buttery oak flavors finish green and herbal.
title: Baron Philippe de Rothschild 2013 Anderra Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Quite staunch and almost sour smelling, with an initial blast of vinegar that later settles on herbal. Flavors of baked beans and herbal fruit carry heat and scouring acidity. Rubbery as well.
title: Santa Alicia 2008 Reserva Carmenère (Maipo Valley)

description: Leather, raisin, earth and lightly baked berry aromas precede a woody, vanilla-infused palate with blackberry and spicecake flavors. Balanced and lively on the tongue, with a dry, barrel-spiced finish. Solid and appealing, but a little oaky.
title: Errazuriz 2009 Single Vineyard Don Maximiano Estate Carmenère (Aconcagua Valley)

description: A dark, saturated color is telling, because this is full and smoky on the nose, with aromas of beef jerky, oak and green herbs. Much like it looks, this Carmenère feels full and saturated. Herbal berry and black plum flavors are peppery and lightly green, while notes of tobacco, coffee and carob comprise the finish.
title: Errazuriz 2015 Max Reserva Carmenère (Aconcagua Costa)

description: Olive and woodspice outmuscle vivid fruit aromas on the nose. The palate is a bit raw and drawing, but it's fresh. Spicy oak adds depth to racy plum and raspberry flavors, with heat stepping in on the finish. Overall this is a fresh, lively version of Carmenère.
title: Viña Casablanca 2012 Nimbus Single Vineyard Carmenère (Rapel Valley)

description: Spicy plum, olive and dry herbal aromas get this crisp, medium-bodied Carmenère off to a fair start. The palate is firm and a touch clampy, with bold acidity. Flavors of pepper, red plum, herbs and oak finish with lasting spice notes and a hint of fennel.
title: Apaltagua 2013 Reserva Carmenère (Apalta)

description: Grainy, resiny oak aromas share space on the nose with herbal black fruit and green scents. This is racy and fresh for Carmenère, with full-force tannins. Herbal, roasted black-fruit and chocolate flavors are long and oaky on the finish, with a mocha note. Drink through 2020.
title: Siegel 2014 Single Vineyard Los Lingues Carmenère (Colchagua Valley)
